entry.title: Migrating from Java 8 to Java 17: A Comprehensive Guide to New Features
entry.summary:
Introduction Java has evolved significantly since the release of Java 8 in 2014. Java 17, released in 2021, brings a host of new features and improvements that can enhance your code's readability, maintainability, and performance. This article will guide you through the key features introduced between Java 8 and Java 17, providing examples of how to migrate your code to take advantage of these new capabilities. Sealed Classes Java 17 introduces sealed classes, a powerful feature that enhances Java's object-oriented programming model and works seamlessly with pattern matching in switch expressions. New Syntax: The sealed keyword declares a sealed class or interface, and the permits clause specifies allowed subclasses: public sealed interface Shape permits Circle, Rectangle, Triangle { }
Su‚Ä¶

entry.title: an unusual place to be
entry.summary: it‚Äôs kind of odd how good i‚Äôve been doing lately; almost scary, even. i think i‚Äôve spent most of my existence being kind of miserable, which in hindsight feels a little bit like a waste. i‚Äôve dealt with plenty of sad and complicated situations (for a lot longer than i should have, really) throughout my life that have made most of my time on this earth leave something to be desired. even when things were going pretty alright externally, internally i always felt like there was this vague feeling of sadness looming over me‚Äîlike maybe i didn't really deserve to be completely happy. at best, i was always just okay and nothing better. but not this time‚Ä¶? i think i can say i‚Äôm actually in a pretty good spot right now and it‚Äôs really weird being able to say so. it‚Äôs something i‚Äôm struggling to believe, even though i know it‚Äôs true. of course there are still some devils i don't really want to tango with yet, but i'll cross that bridge when i get there. for now, i'm having fun. genuine contentment is an uncomfortable feeling but it‚Äôs very much welcome to stay for as long as it‚Äôd like. i hope you've been doing good too. until next time!

entry.title: Impact
entry.summary: I take inspiration from everything and everyone. People- First of all, I don't know if I would be writing this without my brother, Arun. He was the one who cheered me up when I was depressed and got me out of rock bottom. Next are the two seniors from my college, Ambarish and Saptak. I've learnt a lot about life from these 2 guys than anyone. I thank my college debating club for that. The war of Art- This book by Steven Pressfield is one of the best things I've read not because of it's writing but because if it's relatability. I came across this when I was listening to Joe Rogan and he said that he gifted this book to numerous people. I loved the concept of resistance. Previously it was an invisible enemy but now it has a name and concept, which meant it can be defeated. Brandon Sanderson- He is one of my favourite authors now. I fell in love with him after reading the first mistborn trilogy. It's such a perfect series. Then there's the Stormlight Archive and it's huge complex world. I related with a lot of characters on different aspects(especially kaladin). Haikyu- One of my favourite animes of all time. It's about a bunch of highschool volleyball students and their journey. It just feels like home whenever you watch it. There is no one main character. There is a story behind every other character and it's all really nuanced and realistic. This is just life philosophy packed in the neat package of a sports anime. Naval Ravikant- I just randomly found him one day on twitter and the rest is history. He just changed my entire thinking through his ideas and his ideas are simple, no bullshit and actionable(if you've been near me in my club you know that I yap a lot about him). He's everything I want to be in life. We the game of life and quit it.

entry.title: Anti-Militarist Initiative, Anonymous - The left of capital is sabotaging the anarchist movement: let‚Äôs fight back!
entry.summary:
Author: Anti-Militarist Initiative, Anonymous Title: The left of capital is sabotaging the anarchist movement: let‚Äôs fight back! Date: June 2024 Source: https://antimilitarismus.noblogs.org/post/2024/06/14/the-left-of-capital-is-sabotaging-the-anarchist-movement-lets-fight-back/
Soon after the escalation of the war in Ukraine, two completely different tendencies began to emerge under the banner of anarchy. One tendency insists that all inter-state wars are wars of the bourgeoisie against the proletariat, and therefore our participation in them cannot benefit the interests of the exploited class. The other tendency focuses on material, ideological and propaganda work in support of Ukraine‚Äôs state war effort and it sees such an approach as a pragmatic step for future self-organization. R‚Ä¶

entry.title: reflections on the fear of failure and seeking recognition
entry.summary: Hi, I don't know... Lately, I've been thinking a lot about my fear of failure (or maybe I've already failed?), seriously. I'm a very hardworking person... I have courses from prestigious universities (currently over 95 courses), I know four languages and am fluent in three, and I have certifications that many people would love to have, but every day I feel like I'm failing more. I work in the technology sector (and IT has more branches than medicine). Specifically, I specialize in databases and server infrastructure. I even have my own setup at home, including cloud, Git, blog, documentation, and various other things. So, why do I feel the need to talk about this? This [‚Ä¶]

entry.title: Summer Solstice 2024
entry.summary: I heard there was a heatwave going on across the country right now. I spent quite a few years in the Middle East (in my namesake city) where heat is the norm. I grew up in the East Coast (of the US), where we had 4 seasons, and summers were hot and humid. Now, living in a specific part of the West Coast where summers rarely hit above 70F/21.1C (and rarely humid), we are in our own little cocoon. Like right now, it‚Äôs 66F/18.89C (1:52pm). I‚Äôve been sensitive to temperature (and weather changes in general) for as long as I can remember. High temperatures and barometric pressure changes are two big migraine triggers. So if it‚Äôs too hot, raining, or humid‚Ä¶ chances are, I‚Äôll be out of commission, or least somewhat more miserable than an average person. I didn‚Äôt know much about San Francisco (and Bay Area in general) prior to moving here 5+ years ago. I think in some ways, I just got lucky. I have a love/hate relationship with this city (more on that later), but in some ways, I think this is where I‚Äôm meant to be. You see‚Ä¶it doesn‚Äôt rain here often. We have our rainy season end of the year / a few months into the new year, but that‚Äôs pretty much it. In the areas I‚Äôve lived in (and currently live in), it rarely gets hot. The more inland you go, the hotter it could get. Thankfully, the area we are in only gets hot a few weeks in the year. It saves me from suffering too often due to high temperatures. And so, I‚Äôm sending cooling vibes and energy to all those melting in other parts of the country right now. We‚Äôll hit 77F/25C this weekend, and 80F/26.67C at some point next week. Although it may seem mild to many, it‚Äôs not something my body is accustomed to anymore. Anyways, please don‚Äôt hate me for writing this. I feel for those struggling right now with the heat, and I really do wish I could share a little bit of our cooling breeze your way. üêò Reply on Mastodon // üìß Reply by email Subscribe via RSS here

entry.title: the death of mgx
entry.summary: bearblog.dev allows for open discussion and exchange of ideas in a low-stakes way. Putting my thoughts into writing on Bear means there are chances that some readers may open it and engage with it. At that moment, they are actively interpreting and making sense of it based on their own background. I find it liberating to release my raw text entries into the world and see what resonates or sparks new internal discussions for others. There is also a sense of relief in getting ideas that have been swirling in my mind out in the open. Once published, it feels like a task completed. While I don't necessarily stay involved in conversations about my posts, I appreciate seeing the ripple effects as others reflect on or debate the topics.

entry.title: France: With the New Popular Front against the deadly fascist threat!
entry.summary:
When, just after the announcement of the results of the European elections, French President Macron surprised everyone by deciding to dissolve the Parliament and to call general elections for June 30, it was obvious that he aspired to repeat, once again, the successful blackmail thanks to which he had won his two presidential elections: to find himself alone against Marine Le Pen and her far-right party, thus forcing left-wing voters to vote for him in the absence of a left-wing alternative (...) English
/ France, Antifascism

entry.title: The most potent drug - Nostalgia
entry.summary: I just had a nostalgic moment in my exam hall. It was so quiet except for the sound of the ceiling fan and people's footsteps outside. I was looking at the wall clock 45 minutes into my exam (that's what I do in exam halls). This particular time, it brought back memories of my childhood (like in 5th or 6th grade) when I used to play Monopoly with my friends during power cuts. Another memory that recently surfaced depicted my school at 3:30 PM when classes would be over, and there would be clamoring in the corridor until we went to the parking lot. This was triggered by people chatting in front of the exam halls. There is a certain comfort in these noises. Savor these moments when they happen, but don't be jailed by them. Remember, time is a cruel mistress who will make you forget the struggles and just remember the good parts. It's like what Andy says in The Office: "I wish there was a way to know you're in the good old days before you've actually left them."

entry.title: The Growing Risk of Spillovers and Spillbacks in the Bank‚ÄëNBFI Nexus
entry.summary: Nonbank financial institutions (NBFIs) are growing, but banks support that growth via funding and liquidity insurance. The transformation of activities and risks from banks to a bank-NBFI nexus may have benefits in normal states of the world, as it may result in overall growth in (especially, credit) markets and widen access to a wide range of financial services, but the system may be disproportionately exposed to financial and economic instability when aggregate tail risk materializes. In this post, we consider the systemic implications of the observed build-up of bank-NBFI connections associated with the growth of NBFIs.

entry.title: Daniel McGowan - My Own Pearl Harbor
entry.summary:
Author: Daniel McGowan Title: My Own Pearl Harbor Date: Dec 7, 2022 Source: medium.com/@danielmcgowannyc
December 7, 2005 was my own personal Pearl Harbor: the moment that defines the ‚Äòbefore‚Äô and ‚Äòafter‚Äô. The morning started out normal enough. I had plans to stuff some holiday cards for my job and then stop off at a sporting goods store to pick up a gift for my brother-in-law. After that, I was going to babysit for my sister, which I really looked forward to. After some mundane hours in the office, I looked up for a second and a few men were in the doorway of my cube. ‚ÄúDaniel McGowan?,‚Äù they said and before I knew it, I was standing, spun around onto the desk and being cuffed. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going back to Oregon‚Äù is the phrase that sent me spinning. And like that, the past had caught up with‚Ä¶

The award-winning documentary, If A Tree Falls: A Story of the Earth Liberation Front, premiered at Sundance last spring and continues to screen in theaters across the globe. The film, which aired on PBS earlier this fall and is now available on DVD, details the events that led to the imprisonment of environmental activist Daniel McGowan and raises critical questions about ecological crisis, terrorism, and government repression of political activists. Those who see If A Tree Falls are likely to be left with a number of lingering questions. How is Daniel doing now? When will he be re‚Ä¶

Author: Freedom News Title: Toby Shone and the spectre of ‚Äòanarchist terror‚Äô Date: May 9th, 2022 Source: freedomnews.org.uk
Having failed last year to show its much heralded ‚Äúanti-terror‚Äù raids against anarchists in 2020 were justified, the State last week lost a second bid to silence their main target, Toby Shone. The cops‚Äô attempt at targeted repression, using anti-mafia laws against someone unlucky enough to have had drugs in his home during the raids, is just the most recent attack against European anarchists however. It‚Äôs part of a broader pattern which has emerged as energy for the moral panic over fundamentalist Islam subsides. Europe-wide crackdown There is a strain of insurrectionary anarchism in Europe which has maintained itself for decades, and often pops up particularly ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Kinder than necessary
entry.summary: Visited a new cafe. A very cozy place. The aroma made it impossible to resist getting something good to go with the coffee. The walls were decorated with plants and art. One of the pictures caught my eye. It said: Always be a little kinder than necessary. Wise words! And so simple. A free gesture that can brighten someone's day. A little smile. A thumbs up. A "tell the chef the food was delicious". We don't need to exaggerate. We don't have to lie. And we should not suppress any dissatisfaction. But we can actively choose to put kindness first. We can face the world with an open hand instead of a clenched fist. If we had to pick one or the other, then the positive attitude wins every day of the week. Recommended reading: Hidden Battles: The Importance of Choosing Kindness.

entry.title: Robert M. Dowling - On Eugene O‚ÄôNeill‚Äôs ‚ÄúPhilosophical Anarchism‚Äù

Author: Robert M. Dowling Title: On Eugene O‚ÄôNeill‚Äôs ‚ÄúPhilosophical Anarchism‚Äù Date: 2007 Source: The Eugene O‚ÄôNeill Review, Vol. 29 (2007), pp. 50‚Äì72. <http://www.jstor.org/stable/29784831>
Some reasonably well-known facts circulate in O‚ÄôNeill scholarship regarding the subject of this essay‚Äîthe playwright‚Äôs relation to the American anarchist movement in the opening decades of the twentieth century. We know, for example, that as early as 1903, when O‚ÄôNeill was fifteen years old, a minor anarchist cohort calling itself L‚ÄôAvvenire (‚Äúthe Future‚Äù or ‚Äúthe Oncoming‚Äù) existed in New London, Connecticut, the closest thing O‚ÄôNeill could claim as a hometown, and published the radical newsletter II Nostro Programma (‚ÄúOur Program‚Äù or ‚ÄúOur Agenda‚Äù). We also know that the Greenwich Village bohemian Lo‚Ä¶

entry.title: Banks and Nonbanks Are Not Separate, but Interwoven
entry.summary: In our previous post, we documented the significant growth of nonbank financial institutions (NBFIs) over the past decade, but also argued for and showed evidence of NBFIs‚Äô dependence on banks for funding and liquidity support. In this post, we explain that the observed growth of NBFIs reflects banks optimally changing their business models in response to factors such as regulation, rather than banks stepping away from lending and risky activities and being substituted by NBFIs. The enduring bank-NBFI nexus is best understood as an ever-evolving transformation of risks that were hitherto with banks but are now being repackaged between banks and NBFIs.

Under this model, military education was to be extended to all citizens and, instead of spending a long period of time in the barracks, training was given starting from school and then through short-term exercis‚Ä¶

entry.title: Hidden Battles: The Importance of Choosing Kindness
entry.summary: ‚ÄúYou look tired today.‚Äù It wasn‚Äôt meant to be offensive, just an observation from a co-worker whom I respect, when we got on a video call today. The truth is, I‚Äôm exhausted. I‚Äôm typically really good at hiding how I‚Äôm feeling on camera, but not today. Today, my face shows an inkling of how I‚Äôm really feeling inside: Emotionally drained. For the most part, you never really know what people are going through because some people just don‚Äôt show it outwardly. We automatically assume that a smile, or a positive demeanor means that things are going well, but that‚Äôs not always true. Behind that smile, or the ‚ÄúI‚Äôm doing fine‚Äù after an automatic how‚Äôs it going? as a greeting from someone, there might be a hurricane of emotions, anxieties and challenges that are being battled silently. We live in a world where vulnerability is often hidden by a brave face, and it‚Äôs so easy to forget that everyone has their own battles they're working through. A seemingly perfect life on social media, or a blog post, can be really deceptive. It‚Äôs more important now than ever, being in a mostly remote world, to practice kindness and empathy, as you never really know what someone is going through. And so, that‚Äôs me. As a leader in my world of work, I try not to let my personal life interfere with how I lead my team, and yet sometimes it just can‚Äôt be helped. I‚Äôve just been having a difficult time compartmentalizing some things, and I am trying to get better at it. You see, another aunt of mine passed away on Friday, and I haven‚Äôt even processed saying goodbye to my other one before that. I‚Äôve been faced with 4 deaths in 4 weeks in my life, and it‚Äôs just a little bit too much right now. Be kind. Be gentle. üêò Reply on Mastodon // üìß Reply by email Subscribe via RSS here

entry.title: Nonbanks Are Growing but Their Growth Is Heavily Supported by Banks
entry.summary: Traditional approaches to financial sector regulation view banks and nonbank financial institutions (NBFIs) as substitutes, one inside and the other outside the perimeter of prudential regulation, with the growth of one implying the shrinking of the other. In this post, we argue instead that banks and NBFIs are better described as intimately interconnected, with NBFIs being especially dependent on banks both for term loans and lines of credit.

entry.title: Just keep doing the bit (Karma Yoga Edition)
entry.summary: I have been preparing for job interviews (looking to get into genai+backend roles you know). I like building projects and learning new stuff but job search is something that scares me. Partly because of the various uncertainties involved like places to apply, strenous interview processes, where I would work next, what kind of work I will get. It‚Äôs not the first time I am going through this process but it sucks (a lot in the beginning atleast). The other aspect is the grind. Translation: I am not afraid of slap sir, I am afraid of job search I could be solving some leetcode problems right now, I could be applying right now‚Ä¶ I have many things to do even outside job search - oh no - fuck fuck fuck. That‚Äôs sort of the state of my mind - atleast in the background. Till I don‚Äôt build some momen‚Ä¶
